title: 112_s841
content: The Act is titled the "Renewable Energy Market Access Program Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines "energy efficiency product" as a technology that significantly increases energy efficiency in various sectors without causing adverse effects. The Act defines "renewable energy" as energy generated from specific resources like solar, wind, and biofuel. It also includes definitions for "renewable energy product" and "renewable energy resource." Additionally, it defines "small- and medium-sized businesses" as per the Small Business Act. The Small Business Act defines small- and medium-sized businesses based on industry structure, competition, average size, and entry barriers. Cost-sharing assistance is provided for the exportation of energy efficiency and renewable energy products. The Under Secretary for International Trade of the Department of Commerce establishes a program to provide cost-sharing assistance to eligible organizations to improve access to foreign markets for energy efficiency and renewable energy products exported by small- and medium-sized businesses in the United States. Eligible organizations include nonprofit trade associations in the United States or a State or regional entity. The Under Secretary for International Trade of the Department of Commerce sets up a program to offer cost-sharing assistance to eligible organizations promoting the exportation of energy efficiency and renewable energy products. Eligible organizations must submit an application detailing their planned activities to receive assistance through a competitive review process. The Under Secretary prioritizes innovative ideas for improving access to foreign markets for energy efficiency and renewable energy products exported by small- and medium-sized businesses in the United States. The level of cost-sharing assistance is determined based on the plan submitted by eligible organizations. Assistance under this section is limited to 50 percent of the eligible organization's plan cost. The Secretary of Commerce, with input from the Secretary of Energy, must present a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment on the export needs of U.S. businesses dealing with energy efficiency and renewable energy products. Additionally, appropriations of $15,000,000 for 2012, $16,000,000 for 2013, $17,000,000 for 2014, $18,000,000 for 2015, and $19,000,000 for 2016 are authorized for the Commerce Secretary to implement this Act.
